message.content: We refer to DermNet NZ for help. The image given shows a hypertrophic scar, characterized by excessive scar tissue projecting beyond the level of the surrounding skin, but not extending into the underlying subcutaneous tissue. Option A is incorrect because hypertrophic scars do not have hair follicles or other adnexal glands within them. Option C is incorrect because there may be a genetic predisposition to developing hypertrophic scars. Option D is incorrect because hypertrophic scars may extend beyond the borders of the traumatized area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described scar abnormality is a keloid, which is an abnormal response to skin trauma resulting in excessive scar tissue projecting beyond the level of surrounding skin, but not extending into the underlying subcutaneous tissue. Keloids typically occur on the thorax, upper extremities, and earlobes and may occur in families. Option A is incorrect because keloids lack adnexal structures. Option C is incorrect because there is a genetic predisposition for keloid formation. Option D is incorrect because keloids can extend beyond the borders of traumatized areas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the scar matches that of a hypertrophic scar, which is an excessive raised scar that does not extend into the underlying subcutaneous tissue. Option (A) is incorrect as scars do not contain adnexal glands. Option (C) is incorrect as hypertrophic scars may have a genetic predisposition. Option (D) is incorrect as hypertrophic scars can extend beyond the borders of the traumatized area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows a keloid scar, which is an abnormal scar formed as a result of excessive collagen formation during connective tissue repair. Keloid scars project beyond the level of the surrounding skin, but do not extend into the underlying subcutaneous tissue. They can be itchy and there is no association with hair follicles or other adnexal glands. Keloid scars have a genetic basis and may occur more commonly in certain ethnic groups.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a dense, raised, and thickened scar that is not extending into the subcutaneous tissue suggests a hypertrophic scar. Option A is incorrect because scars do not contain hair follicles or glands. Option C is incorrect because there is a genetic component to the development of hypertrophic scars in some individuals. Option D is incorrect because hypertrophic scars can extend beyond the borders of the original injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the scar as dense, raised and projecting beyond the level of surrounding skin is consistent with hypertrophic scarring, which is characterized by excessive scar tissue within the borders of the traumatized area. Option A is incorrect as it refers to a keloid scar, which has hair follicles and other adnexal glands within. Option C is also incorrect as there is evidence of a genetic predisposition to hypertrophic scarring.

Option (A) is incorrect because scars do not contain hair follicles and other adnexal glands. Option (C) is incorrect because there is evidence of genetic predisposition to hypertrophic scar formation. Option (D) is incorrect because hypertrophic scars can extend beyond the borders of the traumatized area.

We refer to dermatology articles for help. The image and description suggest a keloid scar, which is an abnormal proliferation of collagen that extends beyond the border of the original wound and does not have hair follicles or other adnexal structures within. Keloids may have a genetic basis or be linked to specific ethnic groups.
